stream_context.summary: Kaze shows off major off-stream work (a massive “Only Up 64” level for a SimpleFlips competition), then returns to Return to Yoshi’s Island dev: new enemy/prop work (seesaw Goomba gag, Womp construction-worker concept), collision-system improvements, and a real N64 performance pass on a large factory/shipyard-style area. The stream includes a significant N64-only optimization decision (backface culling) and a tricky division-by-zero bug caused by compiler delay-slot scheduling, made worse by maintaining two separate repos.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete N64 performance measurements/optimizations, a compiler-induced crash root cause, and multiple actionable design decisions (N64-only backface culling, how to telegraph events, enemy gag behaviors), plus business context (sponsorship ended) that impacts development sustainability.

findings.summary: Kaze is building an enormous “Only Up 64” level off-stream for a SimpleFlips competition, aiming for the biggest Mario 64 level ever made and hoping it remains N64 compatible; this work temporarily reduces time available for Return to Yoshi’s Island.

Zeina has already created most animations for at least one character/enemy (referenced as “this guy”), but Kaze notes the ‘overseer’ enemy can’t be implemented yet because it still needs animations first.

Kaze added new Tox Box variants (more expressive/higher-quality look) and considers hiding a Yoshi coin inside one of them, implying collectibles may be embedded in enemies/props for exploration rewards.

He implemented collision improvements (including new collision codes) that make movement under/into ceilings and on complex surfaces significantly more stable than vanilla Mario 64; he explicitly highlights that surfaces that were “deadly” in SM64 now behave reliably.

A new level setpiece/mission concept is prototyped: a Goomba attached to a seesaw/plank that falls after a trigger (breaking a box), with Kaze iterating toward a predictable, readable, comedic ‘squish’ outcome; he worries about player readability (box doesn’t look breakable) and wants the behavior to be deterministic enough to script the gag.
Kaze rejects Banjo-Tooie-style heavy inter-world interconnectedness because it creates backtracking; he prefers separate worlds with interconnectedness primarily via the overworld.

The project targets real hardware and uses the Expansion Pak; Kaze says the game likely doesn’t fit into 4MB currently, and while a 4MB mode might be possible by loading areas/code separately, it would be “a lot of extra work for very little extra game.”

A real N64 test reveals a floating point exception in ClipMario: division by zero persisted even after adding a guard because the compiler scheduled the division into the branch delay slot, making it execute unconditionally. Kaze fixes it by rearranging computations into safer instruction slots, and notes emulators (Project64) may not surface divide-by-zero issues the way hardware does.

Major performance tuning on N64: the large factory/shipyard area dips to ~19–22 FPS at worst with backface culling off; enabling backface culling on specific materials boosts worst-case performance to ~28–29 FPS. Kaze decides to apply backface culling on N64 only (keeping the nicer look on emulator) and identifies further gains from deleting never-visible underside polygons and generating a collision map to reduce collision processing.

Kaze avoids streaming dev on his main channel to protect the algorithm and keep the audience game-focused; he also states his YouTube channel is “barely profitable” now that a Brilliant sponsorship deal ended (six-video contract completed), affecting how much he can pay collaborators.
findings.quote: I don’t want to ruin my algorithm… I just care about making a good game.

biobak.summary: Biobak reacts to Kaze’s remark that the dev-only streams are ‘neat for me, sad for you,’ reinforcing that the smaller channel allows experimentation without algorithm pressure; Biobak also affirms Kaze’s approach to ‘fake it’ simulation for the seesaw gag.

badub.summary: Kaze expected Badub to compose music for the level/area being discussed, but says Badub has been “missing in attendance for a bit,” creating uncertainty around near-term music delivery; later Kaze indicates sound design will be finalized near the end once sound-slot budget is clear.
badub.quote: I thought Badub was gonna make [a] song, but Badub’s been missing in attendance for a bit.

zeina.summary: Zeina has produced most animations for a character/enemy Kaze is integrating; Kaze also mentions she is out with friends during this stream (no direct appearance).
zeina.quote: Zeina made the animations for this guy already, or most of them.

findings.summary: Lilaa gives input on technical/design decisions (e.g., advising against leaving an unfixed issue); Kaze uses the exchange to reaffirm his preference for fixing root causes rather than papering over them.
findings.quote: Without affixing the issue it might be a good idea… Thank you Lilaa for your input.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: We only need to fake it well enough that no one notices that it’s fake.
memorable_quotes.context: Sums up his pragmatic approach to convincing setpieces: prioritize player perception over fully accurate physics, as long as the result reads cleanly.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Basically, the compiler decided… to pipeline the division into the delay slot of my branch. So that no matter what happens, I always divide by 0.
memorable_quotes.context: A rare, documentary-worthy example of building for real N64 hardware: low-level compiler/architecture behavior created a crash that wasn’t ‘his fault,’ forcing structural code changes.

key_stories.title: N64 performance rescue via targeted backface culling
key_stories.summary: Testing a large industrial/fleet-factory area on real N64 reveals worst-case performance around 19–22 FPS. Kaze identifies that a large portion of triangles are not being backface culled in the heaviest views and flips backface culling on for specific materials.
key_stories.challenge: Keep a massive, visually dense level playable on original hardware without sacrificing the intended look on emulator/modern play.
key_stories.process: Measure FPS on N64 from worst camera angles; compare visual impact of backface culling; decide to apply it selectively and potentially only on N64; plan additional passes (delete unseen underside geometry, generate collision map, adjust draw-distance systems).
key_stories.outcome: Worst-case FPS improves to ~28–29 FPS (playable), with a plan to keep the nicer render on emulator while using culling on N64.

key_stories.title: Division-by-zero crash caused by delay-slot scheduling
key_stories.summary: A new ClipMario change causes a floating point exception on N64. Even after adding a guard against dividing by zero, the crash persists because the compiler schedules the division into the branch delay slot, executing it unconditionally.
key_stories.challenge: A hardware-only crash that emulators don’t reliably flag, plus the difficulty of reasoning about generated MIPS code and delay slots.
key_stories.process: Reproduce on N64; locate crash address; identify divisor becoming 0; realize compiler reorders/pipelines the divide into delay slot; restructure code to move computations so the divide can’t execute before the guard resolves.
key_stories.outcome: A safer code structure that avoids unconditional divide-by-zero on N64; reinforces need for hardware testing and awareness of compiler/codegen quirks.
key_stories.key_quote: That’s not a bug in the code… I need to move some of these computations into new slots.

key_stories.title: Two repos, twice the fixes
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovers the same ClipMario bug affects both Return to Yoshi’s Island and the separate Only Up 64 repo. Fixing the same issue in two places becomes immediate overhead.
key_stories.challenge: Parallel development across multiple ROMhack repos increases maintenance cost and risk of diverging fixes.
key_stories.process: Apply the fix in both repositories and vocalize frustration with duplicated maintenance.
key_stories.outcome: Bug fixed, but highlights a structural workflow issue worth addressing (shared engine code, submodules, or cherry-pick discipline).
key_stories.key_quote: This is why I hate having two repos, because now I need to fix this in two places at once.

open_questions.topic: Collision system upgrade (new collision codes, ceiling stability)
open_questions.context: Kaze claims noticeable stability improvements versus vanilla SM64, especially when walking into ceilings and on complex triangle-defined surfaces; he treats it as a meaningful engine upgrade.
questions: What exactly changed in the collision system (data structures, numeric tolerances, edge/vertex handling, ceiling checks)?
Was this driven by a specific broken area/bug in Return to Yoshi’s Island, or was it proactive engine work?
How do you validate collision improvements (test maps, automated cases, N64 vs emulator parity)?
Do these changes affect level design freedom (steeper slopes, tighter ceilings, more complex geometry) compared to vanilla SM64?

open_questions.topic: N64-only rendering differences as a design policy
open_questions.context: Kaze prefers the visual look with backface culling off on emulator, but needs it on N64 for performance. He suggests making backface visibility an emulator-only ‘nice look’ feature.
questions: Do you want Return to Yoshi’s Island to look identical on emulator and real hardware, or is ‘hardware-first’ with emulator enhancements acceptable?
How will you communicate or manage differences (graphics options menu, auto-detection, documented ‘accuracy’ modes)?
What other rendering compromises might become N64-only (LOD, fog usage, draw distance, effects)?

open_questions.topic: Collision map generation as a performance lever
open_questions.context: Kaze notes they haven’t created a collision map yet and expects it to significantly improve performance by reducing collision processing cost.
questions: What is your collision-map pipeline (manual tagging, automated generation, spatial partitioning like grids/quadtrees/BSP)?
How big is the performance hit currently from collision triangle checks in this level, and how will you measure the gain after the map is added?
Does the collision map affect gameplay bugs (e.g., missed collisions, edge cases) and how will you QA it on N64?

open_questions.topic: Sound/music pipeline uncertainty (Badub absent; end-of-project sound design)
open_questions.context: Kaze expected music from Badub but says he’s been absent recently; Kaze also plans to do sound design late once sound-slot limits are known.
questions: What’s the agreed process for track requests, iteration, and deadlines with Badub (and what happens when he’s unavailable)?
What are the hard technical limits for sounds in your build (number of step sounds, SFX bank limits, memory)?
How do you decide when a level’s ‘timing’ is final enough for sound design to start (setpieces like the seesaw, squish gag, factory ambience)?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly mentions a recent playtest on Course 2 with changes made afterward but does not detail what was learned or altered.
questions: Who conducted the Course 2 playtest (team vs external), and what was the test prompt?
What specific changes did you make to Course 2 afterward (difficulty, readability, camera, objectives, pacing)?
Did the playtest reveal any broader design rules you’re applying across the project?
